question: 'Morning, Jimmy, think you could squeeze me in? Bang-bang. You're a thief, Jimmy. I don't do skies. Hi, guys.
answer: G'damn, Price, you tuna sucking piece of raw meat -- whatchyou goin' to Zambeze for?

question: Thought I'd get some great shots of your head gettin' blown to smithereens.
answer: Smithereens?! Be a great fuckin' picture, eh?

question: Be a prize winner.
answer: Ya think so? Trade ya some greenies for a joint. I gotta have a joint.

question: I'm on the wagon, man, sorry.
answer: Ahh. Dope-wise, this place sucks. Lotta fuckin' coons around here, eh?

question: I thought you were fighting for the Government?
answer: I am. This is the Government.

question: These are the Rebels.
answer: Fuck they are. This is a Government convoy to Calunda.

question: This is the Abou-Deian Revolutionary Front.
answer: You're shitting me. These guys be pissed if they knew, eh? This is the dumbest motherfucker I ever signed up for. Don't pay shit either. Nicaragua. That's the spot. Cheap shrimp, lotta rays -- real thin in the spook department too, dig? Well hell... I wonder where the fuckin' Guvmint is?

question: Hold it! Hold it!
answer: Well, I guess we know where the Guvmint is.

question: You can walk to work from here.
answer: Convenient, ain't it? My brother just got married.

question: I don't know your brother. What's this?
answer: Great shit, eh? U.S. Gummint offers this house to any Cuban pilot flying Migs for the Rebels who chooses to defect to America with a Russian jet. We know they ain't gonna run off with no planes -- but the Rebs don't -- They're scared. They start thinking about that swimming pool. Damn near smell that chlorine. Starts workin' on 'em, and pretty soon they don't let the Cubies near a Mig. Use their own spook pilots and destroy their own air force in a week. Guaran-fuckin- teed.

question: C.I.A.?
answer: Smartest guys in the world. Hey, you gotta scoop here, eh? You'll be famous.

question: Maybe.
answer: I gotta run... have a good one.

question: "...and so this strange war that features two provincial governments, three rival liberation fronts, and at least twenty-five tribal associations, grinds into its seventh year..." "...The Battle for the Airfield at Abou Deia is just another chapter in this endless story. From Ndjamena, Chad, this is Claire Stryder." No -- you didn't hear any music -- must be the connection. Okay? So long. Alex, don't play that God damn thing when I'm filing. We're late.
answer: It's my party -- we'll be late. You called it a "strange war" and an "endless story." If you filed that story for me, I'd say you were editorialishing.

question: I like to editorialize. You drunk?
answer: Drunk? Only with the memories of making love with you on the plains of Fianga as the first Army of Liberation marched in and opened fire.

question: And freed the Proletariat.
answer: Right.

question: I'm going to the party without you.
answer: Christ, I don't want to go to this stupid party. I'm bad at false modesty.

question: You're great at it. Alex, you're going to make a great anchorman in New York and undoubtedly I could be a Pulitzer Prize winning hostess -- but I'm not going with you.
answer: You can work out of the East Coast. We'll get a place on Long Island and burn our suitcases.

question: I still like suitcases.
answer: Every Saturday night we'll have a party... invite all our friends, sit out on the veranda and interview each other.

question: I've done all that.
answer: I haven't. Well, God dammit, I'm getting tired of memorizing who's the president of the... Republic of Maldives.

question: Mamoon Abdul Gayoom.
answer: Yeah, he succeeded Mamoon Abdul Gayeem. And I'm tired of Third World elevators. Don't leave me.

question: I already have.
answer: Fuck Abou Deia and New York. I'm going to Nicaragua with you.

question: No.
answer: I've heard it's a neat little war with a nice hotel.

question: Oh. I didn't know you were here.
answer: Sure you did. You were taking pictures of me all over the room.

question: Well... yeah... you looked great. Why aren't you partying?
answer: In a minute.

question: I printed that up for Alex.
answer: It wouldn't be the greatest thing you could give him right now... We just split up.

question: Jesus, I'm sorry. Who left who this time?
answer: I'm the villain... I thought it could be a little cleaner this time -- me in Central America, him in New York.

question: That's pretty clean.
answer: But he's decided to go to Nicaragua too.

question: To cover you or the war?
answer: To cover everything. No. For godsakes, Russell, listen.

question: I don't want to wait for you again. We've been circling each other since the Montreal Olympics.
answer: You're a genius of bad timing. I'm going back to the party. This is a great shot.

question: Thanks.
answer: I've heard the light in Nicaragua's even better.

question: Wait here.
answer: Welcome to Managua.

question: You have something to do with this?
answer: Well... I thought of calling your photographs "Pictures from a Lost War"... I'm great at captions -- the New York editors loved it since none of them knew where the hell Chad was anyway -- it legitimized their ignorance, got you a cover, me a feature, and packaged a class struggle in two words. Nifty, eh?

question: Nifty. I'm Russell Price.
answer: I'm sorry... this is Isela Cruz. She works for the hotel and helps out as a translator.

question: "Misunderstanding?!" "Down here" it's called a war. It started in nineteen thirty. Before you were born.
answer: My Spanish is a little out of shape -- what'd he say?

question: He said he considers it an honor to be able to photograph our war.
answer: Russell's got a way with words.

question: Rafael? Comandante Rafael. He is either a Marxist dupe of Russia and Cuba... ...or the most popular leader of a most popular democratic revolution. Take your pick.
answer: I don't really give a damn... but the guy's got a great face. How would he like to be photographed?

question: You'd never find him.
answer: Wanta lay odds?

question: You would lose. You must excuse me.
answer: Just one more thing -- is Rafael owned by the C.I.A. or the K.G.B.? I'll figure out the rest.

question: Mr. Price... the world is not divided into East and West anymore. It is divided into North and South. By the time you people figure that out -- it will be too late. Congratulations on your cover.
answer: So far this war's got it all over Africa.

question: So far this war's got it all over Africa.
answer: You're gonna have a ball. Hands off. I need an interpreter more than you do right now.

question: You still hanging in there with Claire?
answer: I'm hanging in there like an interim post-war government waiting for the palace to be overrun... by younger men.

question: Younger men.
answer: Hi, Alex... Russell! When did you get in?

question: Just now.
answer: You're not going to believe this -- I just beat you guys and everybody else here to a story... ...exclusive... eat your heart out.

question: What'd ya get?
answer: I've just been promised a private interview with Tacho.

question: Well...
answer: "Well"... you finished your assignment in Chad?

question: Got Africa all wrapped up and pouched to my editor.
answer: You're going to love this war, Russell... there's good guys, bad guys, cheap shrimp... And Alex is still singing in the background. I missed you.

question: Jesus... he's doing it on purpose.
answer: Alex is one of the world's leading experts on military strategy. Well, hell, I just got off the boat... gimme the scoop on Nicaragua...

question: Well... about sixty years ago the U.S. Marines invaded to protect American business interests and put down a peasant revolt led by a little man who wore a giant cowboy hat -- his name was Augusto Sandino... In nineteen thirty-four he was murdered at a peace conference, and the Somoza family has ruled ever since...
answer: No, no, no... I don't mean the stuff about the peasants -- I mean the real stuff.

question: The "real" stuff?... you mean a history of class struggle in agrarian societies?
answer: No, c'mon!

question: Oh. Okay... well... Just a couple things. One -- there's only two kinds of beer available -- Tona and Victoria. Victoria's better. And two -- if you see Miss Panama hanging around the hotel bar -- hot, hot, hot -- but don't touch. She belongs to Tacho, and if anybody gets caught with her then El Presidente has promised to personally cut off the guy's...
answer: Pecker?

question: Yeah... and throw it into Lake Managua.
answer: Jesus.

question: And the lake's already polluted.
answer: Is there anybody here we don't know?

question: No.
answer: G'damn, Price... kudos on the African snaps. Jeez, Claire, I haven't seen you since...

question: Three Mile Island.
answer: Yeah... shit... Holiday Inn, right?

question: Jesus... Louis Jordan walks in, and I'm sitting with the Everly Brothers.
answer: Before you fall in love -- that's Marcel Jazy... friend of wine, women, and Somoza. They say he's a businessman...

question: Tell him we have pictures. Tell him there were pieces of body in the piano, and somebody was singing, "I Left My Heart in San Francisco." What's he got better than that? Forget the Pope, Charlie. Every week you got the Pope somewhere. This is a very big story down here because it's the first sign of fighting in Managua. Yeah, well get a map and look up Nicaragua -- ya drive to New Orleans and turn left. Like hell I'm editorializing, the whole thing happened in a roomful of C.I.A. and press. What do you want?! How do I know they were C.I.A.? They wore name tags, what do you think? We're backing a Fascist again -- I know that ain't news, but see if you can find an angle!
answer: Hey! There's fascists and then there's fascists, right? Be careful how you throw words like that around.

question: We don't have any pictures of Rafael because nobody knows where the son of a bitch is, and anybody crazy enough to go after him... ...is liable to get his nuts shot off. Yeah, well g'bye... Who the fuck are you?
answer: Hub Kittle. I'm with Lewitsky and Knupp -- New York. We have a client down here.

question: Who?
answer: President Somoza. I know, I know... But there's an untold story here. I mean, the man has a point of view too, right? We got a national anthem contest going on right now, and you guys are ignoring it. Lotta human interest.

question: Cuanto? Veinte. What is this? I'm a journalist! Journalista, journalista!
answer: Cigarillo?

question: Priest? What are you doing here?
answer: The government accused me of using the church to hide Rebels and guns.

question: Governments are always wrong, eh?
answer: This time they're right. Who are you?

question: Un periodista.
answer: Whose side are you on?

question: I don't take sides. I take pictures.
answer: No sides?

question: No.
answer: Periodista Puta, todos periodistas son putas. Go home.

question: Soy un periodista. That film is half way to New York by now. Forget it.
answer: You throw a journalist in jail -- it gets in the papers. You walk all over the same press credentials you pass out. I demand to speak to someone in authority or I'll go to Tacho myself... I don't understand you -- you're big and strong and handsome but you're not so smart! You should be trying to seduce us!

question: Claire!
answer: You're okay?

question: I'm fine -- what're you doing here? These guys are goons.
answer: They love being beaten up by a woman I've been looking for you all night -- why'd they lock you up?

question: I don't know. Taking pictures. The usual. Jazy got me released.
answer: Jazy?! You think there's a story there?

question: Ahh... C.I.A. stories are all alike. I wanta find Rafael.
answer: You need help?

question: No. You?
answer: No. When should we start.

question: I figure you probably want to do a little research on the history of Marcel Jazy's business connections in the third world countries with C.I.A. influence...
answer: Oh. I assumed you'd just look him in the eye and say "Gimme a break, for crissakes, Marcel, are you a spy or aren't you?"

question: Spy is such an odd word, Mr. Price... nobody is a... 'spy'... anymore.
answer: Russell prefers pictures to words...

question: You don't have to apologize... you're journalists.
answer: And you're a businessman?

question: No agua. If she dove in, I assure you she wouldn't notice. Sweetheart, the Guerrillas knocked out the pumping station on the road to Masaya, and we must ration water for the time being. Next week maybe things will be better. Maybe you should. You were arrested because the Guardia are clowns who specialize in excess. You were released because I told them to release you.
answer: These are not the normal duties of a businessman.

question: But they are the normal duties of a... spy, eh? You win, I'm a spy. There, are you happy? I feel better. Now we can relax. You can turn off your little thing. Oh, I trust you won't say anything to hurt me. In some ways I'm a terrible spy. I used to be much better at it, but now it seems everyone knows who I am. I have too many girlfriends. I like to be photographed. I talk too much. I always talk too much... but my girlfriends like that... No matter. You know who she is? That's Miss Panama. Do you know who that is? She's in love with me. I've got to get some water in the pool. And once a week I have lunch with President Somoza to discuss security measures against the Sandinista insurgents, but all he wants to talk about is Miss Panama... he's worried about her.
answer: Because he thinks she's seeing another man?

question: Did you dream about Miss Panama last night?
answer: I dreamed about you.

question: Have a good time?
answer: Yeah... so'd you.

question: And old war injury flaring up?
answer: Is the tape on?

question: Of course.
answer: I was on the deck of the U.S.S. Pueblo catching some rays when the North Koreans attacked... took a bullet right in the chest, but by luck I had an extra roll of high speed ektachrome in this pocket right here... over the heart...

question: And the bullet ricocheted off the film, grazed your cheek, and saved your life.
answer: You heard about it?! I was lucky.

question: Did anyone ever die next to you in combat?
answer: Yeah.

question: What did you do?
answer: F.8 at a sixtieth.

question: That's an old joke. My question was serious.
answer: So was I. You ever dream about me?

question: Once.
answer: How was I?

question: Fast. I'm basically a coward, Russell, I hope you understand that. I hope we don't get shot.
answer: Me too.

question: You must come and help us... one more time.
answer: No, please... Americans? Journalists? Ah! I put my autograph on this ball.

question: Pedro! There is no time to waste.
answer: When you get back to the United States, I want you to give this ball to Tippy Martinez for me. He is from Nicaragua.

question: Enrique is dead! Roberto has disappeared! The Guardia has the church, and we need you!
answer: You come, eh? Can they come with us?

question: They're away.
answer: What the fuck are you doing here?

question: What the fuck are you doing here?
answer: Awright, awright -- you're lookin' good... how ya like Nicaragua?

question: It's beautiful.
answer: Shitload o' greasers though, eh?

question: Hello sweetheart, this is your mother. I'm in Leon and I miss you. Don't worry about me -- it's not dangerous at all. I guess you can't believe what you hear on the news. I'll put this this tape in the mail when I get back to Managua, but knowing what the mail service is like, I may be home before it arrives. I think about you all the time and hope I can make it back before you graduate from Jr. High. I love you and I'll finish this letter when I get back to the hotel.
answer: I know who shot Pedro. I knew somebody was in the tower.

question: Why didn't you tell the guerrillas?
answer: I don't know... then they would've killed him I guess. I didn't want to interfere.

question: It wasn't an easy choice.
answer: I think I made the wrong one.

question: You didn't take any pictures when it was over.
answer: I didn't? I picked up a gun. Jesus. Is something happening to us?

question: Yes.
answer: Are you asleep?

question: No.
answer: G'morning.

question: What are you doing?
answer: You look beautiful.

question: How long have you been doing this?
answer: 'Bout ten frames. Wait'll you see the pictures -- you look great.

question: I'll bet I look great -- give me the film.
answer: After they're printed.

question: I'll develop them myself -- give it to me or I'll start taping what you say in your sleep.
answer: I talk in my sleep?

question: Girl's names and F-stops. Terrible.
answer: Call the office. I don't want to go to work today.

question: How was Matagalpa? You find anything?
answer: Oh!

question: Oh. How was Leon?
answer: Bloody.

question: Yeah... I'll bet... Claire... I'm tired of Nicaragua.
answer: You haven't been here very long.

question: Long enough, lets face it, you were right... everybody was right.
answer: About what?

question: My cheekbones. What do you think of 'em?
answer: I like your cheekbones. Alex, are you all right?

question: This is a face made for television.
answer: You decided to go with the network.

question: Is he a good fuck?
answer: Alex...

question: That's a reasonable question for a reporter to ask, isn't it?! I shoulda never come down here, eh? This is the way it's going to be. I'll make a shitload of money in television for just sitting there. I'm gonna show up to work at Rockefeller Center every morning and they're gonna hand me the news with my coffee and toast. I shoulda never come down here, eh? This war down here belongs to you guys, okay? I'm on tommorrow's plane.
answer: Alex...

question: We're grownups, Russell... Most of us.
answer: You two wanta happy snap?

question: No happy snaps.
answer: Okay, okay... I'll just... be over here.

question: I'm a personal friend of Tacho's. Don't look, huh? No mire!
answer: Don't get hurt.

question: Ahh, I'm a chicken, don't worry. Alex, listen to me...
answer: Yeah?

question: You're late to your own luncheon, Mr. President -- we can schedule this for another time.
answer: Nonsense -- let them wait. We are a stunning couple, eh? My stomach is very flat -- I've been working out.

question: We are a stunning couple. Mr. President, you own one fifth of all the land in Nicaragua, you own the shipping port, the national airlines, the Mercedes dealership...
answer: I am on a salt free diet...

question: Do you always hold hands with reporters?
answer: This is my mother and father. They were very special to me. Every Sunday morning I drive out to the cemetery and put flowers on their grave. I think people should know that.

question: Listen, Russell, let's grow up. It's very easy to fall in love with the underdog, eh? But there's an upside and downside to this thing -- just wanta remind you... this stuff about a "Revolution of Poets" is crap.
answer: But it's great P.R. So what's the upside?

question: Simple. And it could happen. Somoza destroys the terrorist insurgents, rebuilds the country, shitcans the purveyors of excess, stabilizes the cordoba, and is finally beloved as the savior of Nicaragua. Our pal. Got a smoke?
answer: What's the downside?

question: My people love me. My stomach is flat. Did I say that already? No matter. It is flat.
answer: There are reports that the Guardia operates a torture chamber at Coyotepe.

question: I like this song.
answer: Since the earthquake in 1972 destroyed half of Managua, over three hundred million dollars in foreign relief aid have poured into the country, yet nothing has been re-built. It is said that the money has gone into your pocket.

question: I love the press, I really do. Some of my best friends are journalists.
answer: Ecuador, Mexico, Peru, Brazil, and Panama are reportedly on the verge of breaking off diplomatic relations with your regime. Would you comment?

question: Russell, excuse me... but I've just been put in a rather embarrassing position. Mrs. Somoza would like her picture taken with Miss Panama. In color?
answer: How the hell could Tacho find Rafael.

question: Russell, please... I have my hands full...
answer: Is Tacho lying again? They did kill him, didn't they?

question: Everybody smile.
answer: One more, please! Una mas, por favor? We help each other, right? Could you move your girlfriend into the sun...

question: What do you need?
answer: Is Rafael alive or dead?

question: I don't know.
answer: Just one more -- thank you. I thought you knew everything?

question: What do I know, eh? Tacho needs a victory very badly... he needs to prove to Jimmy Carter that he is still winning. He thinks Rafael's death is the proof he needs.
answer: Carter don't need proof. He just sent twenty-five million in new arms to Tacho. I'm sorry... almost got it here.

question: No, no... the arms shipment has been delayed in New Orleans because Jimmy is getting nervous.
answer: The State Department's gonna pull the plug on Tacho?! Pardon my French -- but whose fucking side are you on?

question: ...I work for everybody. If there is a transition of power, I facilitate a relationship with the new people. If there is not, I facilitate the status quo. Either way, I facilitate.
answer: Great job.

question: I send messages to Jimmy and I tell him that the Revolution is a flood that cannot be stopped but it can be controlled... nobody listens... I can't even get a little water in my pool.
answer: Rough ain't it. Thank you everybody, very nice. I don't think Rafael is dead. I'm gonna find him.

question: They say he's very handsome. It would make a wonderful picture, eh?
answer: Con permiso -- who controls what today?

question: Do you know why we're here... exactly?
answer: Mr. Price doesn't do anything before announcing it first in the bar. It's a good story. You'll be more famous.

question: Rafael's tent?
answer: Venga, companeros.

question: You're crazy.
answer: If Washington thinks Rafael is dead, they will ship the arms to Somoza. Do you understand.

question: Yeah. Commandante... Soy un periodista. I don't do things... like this.
answer: I spend my whole life separating how I feel from how I think and what I see from what I say -- that's called journalism, isn't it? It's disciplined. It civilized. It involves distinctions. I'm great at distinctions. I wish I wasn't so good at them. Sometimes I envy you -- you don't make any -- it's very convenient. The only time I don't worry about all those things is when I'm with my daughter.

question: Or when you're in bed.
answer: Yes! My job is to find a story, then tell a story -- whatever it is -- because I believe that if enough people hear enough stories then somehow, through information alone, we all have a better chance to survive. I believe in information. That's a very romantic streak I have running through me -- maybe it's a weakness. Information is good -- lack of information is bad. Simple, eh?

question: Not so simple.
answer: You're God damn right it's not. You take that picture you'll take it for all the right reasons -- I understand.

question: I'm not gonna take it.
answer: That's fine for you. But do I go back and say I interviewed Rafael? Do I go back and say I missed the biggest story of the war? Or do I say Rafael was stone cold dead -- that's the information, isn't it? Or do I say he entertained us all in his inimitably charismatic manner around the ol' revolutionary campfire? Can we throw up our arms and say we fell in love with the querillas because their cause was... sympathetic? Journalists don't fall in love. Which story do you want me to tell?

question: Do what you want to do.
answer: Christ, what the fuck are we doing here?

question: I want to be here. With you. What do you want.
answer: I want this war to end. I'm not going to tell the world that Rafael is dead.

question: I love you.
answer: I think I love you.

question: We've got to tell Alex what happened.
answer: No way.

question: I'll tell him. He deserves to know.
answer: We don't owe him anything!

question: We owe him that! He got you started in this business... he covered for your missed deadlines and made excuses for your unprofessional attitude before the world fell in love with your pictures... Before kids fresh out of journalism school were rushing off to any war they could to interview bullets and take pictures of bodies -- like Price! He took care of you before you were hot!
answer: He wouldn't understand.

question: Before Nicaragua you wouldn't understand. I'm not sure I exactly understand. What are we going to do?
answer: I'll take Alex to find Rafael -- we'll go to Sebaco on the road to Matagalpa -- the Guardia heavily control the area and they're scared right now -- they'll never let us through. We won't be able to get near Rafael. Alex will understand -- and we'll turn around and drive back without a story.

question: That's a lie!
answer: Tell me about lies!

question: I don't want to tell him either.
answer: We may not be able to find him, y'know...

question: We may not be able to find him, y'know...
answer: I've got supreme confidence in you. Claire looks good, eh?

question: Everybody looks good in the tropics.
answer: Since I haven't been able to find Isela since coming back, you're going to have to translate for me -- what the hell does that mean?

question: Alex... I love her.
answer: And she 'thinks' she loves you.

question: It's past the thinking stage.
answer: I'd like to know something -- it probably doesn't matter in the great final scheme of things... but I'm interested... Did you ever lay a hand on her before she left me?

question: No!
answer: That's the truth?

question: Don't worry. I put this in your name.
answer: No pictures, eh? Might look bad.

question: You get paid by the body or by the hour?
answer: I get paid the same way you do. What the fuck you doin' in Sebaco -- this place's about to blow... ain't it?

question: You didn't have to nail Pedro.
answer: Who's Pedro?

question: Them? C'mere. You too. If your mug shows up in this box... and ya try to make it through Sebaco... I owe yer ass.
answer: Who gives you the pictures?

question: What's this, an interview? I ain't that dumb.
answer: Off the record.

question: Some-motherfucker-took-my-fucking- pictures-I-don't-fucking-know-what- happened! Fuck me!
answer: Didn't you ship the film to New York?

question: I developed it in my room. Jesus Christ, Alex?!
answer: Slow down. It wasn't your fault if somebody stole your stuff...

question: It was.
answer: What about Rafael?

question: Algo no esta aqui. Fotografias. Negativos, negativos!
answer: Commandante Cinco's body was just found on the road to Matagalpa. I don't think it's Jazy.

question: Oates said it was a Frog. How many Frenchmen you know around here? Jazy ain't 'facilitating' shit.
answer: Christ! Are we looking for negs or prints?

question: Anything.
answer: Que quiere?

question: Que quiere?
answer: Donde esta senor Jazy?

question: No esta aqui.
answer: Que quienes?

question: What the hell are you talking about?
answer: I think what he's trying to say -- what we're trying to say -- is that things aren't exactly what they seem to be.

question: Well, they don't "seem" to be that great so I can't wait for this one... Hey, here we are! Two guys in the tropics in love with the same dame... bullets flying!
answer: Alex! That's not why we're here.

question: Oh yeah? I left the country because of him... ...and I came back because of him... And now the cutest couple in town has me looking up a horse's ass on a midnight tour of Managua. What are we doing here?
answer: Rafael is dead.

question: You saw too many bodies? That's a lot of bodies. You stupid son of a bitch. Did he talk you into it?
answer: No! I wanted Rafael to be alive.

question: In some way I understand him doing it, I don't like it but I understand... but you?
answer: I'd do it again.

question: You two have, of course, just served me up your balls -- if that's what they're called -- on a platter. I can bury you both. You're handing me your careers. Well, Jesus Christ... this is a motherfucking story, Russell... What am I supposed to do with it?
answer: Anything you want.

question: Damn air conditioning.
answer: I wish I was home.

question: C'mere.
answer: Do you think it's almost over?

question: Alex... let's go back.
answer: Jazy's probably sitting in the bar laughing at us. Which way's the hotel?

question: I don't know.
answer: I'll ask her... be right back.

question: Get my bill and get me a cab, hey, amigo! Cabs! I'm sorry, Claire...
answer: Heard from Russell?

question: Nobody has.
answer: Wanta help me find him?

question: Who are you?
answer: They are my friends.

question: Him or him or her?
answer: Well, here we are, eh?

question: Assassin! Shut up!
answer: The boys are confused -- they think I had their family killed.

question: "Murder" is a word for criminals. I have a job to protect the stability of a continent. Please...
answer: You got caught by some boys?

question: Yes. Poets too, I imagine. Is your recorder on?
answer: Yes.

question: Good. I have a speech to make. I like you people, but you are sentimental shits. You fall in love with the poets, the poets fall in love with the Marxists, the Marxists fall in love with themselves. The country is destroyed with rhetoric, and in the end we are stuck with tyrants.
answer: Shut up!

question: Un minuto, por favor. They are journalists.
answer: Periodistas! Take this picture! I'm going to blow his head off.

question: Somoza? He is a tyrant too, of course. A butcher. But finally that is not the point, you see. If we wish to survive -- we have a choice of tyrants, and for all the right reasons, your poets choose the wrong side.
answer: Fotografia!

question: You okay? Russell... what did Alex do?
answer: Nothing. He asked for directions. We gotta get outta sight -- half the fucking army's looking for me...

question: They're not looking for me. Let me have the film... ...if I can't get to the hotel I'll come back here...
answer: Aw, Christ... I've wrecked everything else, at least let me take care of you here.

question: Russell... it's more dangerous being with you than being alone.
answer: Don't get hurt.

question: That's great advice. Yes... perhaps they will. Have you seen La Guardia? I don't know. Yes.
answer: Alex.
